title: How to use copyrighted music on YouTube - Quora

response.answer_text: Your CDs and iTunes songs are licensed for personal & private home enjoyment, so you can always share those with friends in your home (even if you put them on a slideshow or PowerPoint to share in your home). But the moment you post that online or play it in a public setting or put it on a DVD to share, the copyright law comes into play. If you upload it through YouTube’s server, that’s considered distribution (even if you make it private or unlisted) and so it’s subject to their Terms of Service and U.S. Copyright law. The only way to upload a video containing copyrighted audio or video clips and not eventually receive a copyright flag is to obtain permission from the copyright holder. Ideally you would have done this before you posted it, but since you’ve received copyright notifications, click those to see who the intellectual property rights owner is (usually a company or agency) and review what remedy they’re proposing. If they’ve opted to simply monetize it (run ads on your video) or block it in some countries and you’re OK with that, no worries, just click the acknowledgement that you understand and are OK with it. That doesn’t necessarily mean they’re giving permission; it’s just a concession for convenience’ sake (in other words, they’re not going to sue you as long as they can do the remedy they’ve chosen). NOTE: They can rescind or change this at any time, so it’s always best to get permission on the front end. If they’re stripping out songs altogether or blocking the video because it contains that content, you’ll need to contact that rights owner to request permission to use it…and fair warning: If you’re using entire songs, it’s unlikely. Shorter excerpts on a personal video for a small audience where there’s no profit or loss of sales? Likely. But the copyright owner has complete say in what they’ll permit and how because it’s their property you’re wanting to use. Once you’ve obtained written permission, you can re-upload and then dispute the copyright notification, giving as your justification for the exemption the reason that you have obtained the permission or have a license to use it (usually you have to give enough details that the rights holder can verify this). Another (far better) option is to not use copyrighted music at all. Either produce your own or buy, license, or obtain some royalty-free non-copyrighted music that’s intended for this type of use. One great example of this (which I love and use in many personal videos) is Bensound.com. They have both free and paid licenses depending on how you want to use their work, and on the free ones they usually permit it (license it) as long as you’re willing to follow their terms, which usually means proper acknowledgement/credit and a referral link to their site. Another such service (geared more to professional video producers, but with single-song options and reasonable per-track pricing) is NarratorTracks. Or use music which is licensed through Creative Commons, as Todd Gardiner suggested.

Do people actually read the question before they answer? This bloke wants to know how he CAN GET PERMISSION TO USE THE MUSIC LEGALLY? So here is what you would need to do but chances are that this will be a frustrating experience: You need permission by the rights owner which is usually the publisher of the music. This is not necessarily the label company that produced the music! You would contact the publisher and ask for procedures to grant you the right to use the music in a YouTube video. But: As most of those guys “have lots to do”, chances are that you will not even receive an answer because they think you are just a private guy with no money to spend. Sad but true. There are also places like the GEMA in Germany who make sure that people get money when their stuff is played in the radio, online, on TV in movies … wherever. Probably you will be more successful trying to get the rights there. If the stuff you are doing is not commercial work, your chances are not bad to actually get the rights for a reasonable amount of money. Companies like GEMA do have some fair online packages. Not sure how it works in other countries than Germany, though. If all of this does not lead to anywhere: Replace the songs with some royalty free music: There are tons of websites where you can buy awesome music for little money regarding usage rights.

You need to contact the record label or publisher of the track you would like to use - because you need to acquire the synchronization license from the copyright owner. This could end up in a big amount of money as the copyright owner can ask anything in exchange for the “SYNC” license. An alternative would be to use music from a royalty free music library where composers upload their music and authorise the music libraries to sell those sync license on their behalf. The price for such is license is usually around 30 USD per track and the process is extremely easy and instant. If you are looking for a certain track you may also go for a “sound alike” track in royalty free music libraries. It will not cost a fortune and you may end up creating the same feeling as the popular track you intented to use. Another advantage of using music from royalty free music libraries is that in most cases, composers upload different versions of the same track (30sec, 60 sec, full track, full track without lead instrument etc). This may save significant time of track editing.

You must COVER it with your own voice, band or instrument. You CAN’T use the original recording without getting a license and permission from the record label. YouTube (and only YouTube) has sync license agreements with 95% of all publishers. So if YOU make a cover version of a song YOU can post that as a performance video or even a concept video on YOUTUBE. They also generally let you post actual artist recordings provided you DON’T use them in original films or videos, but just show the lyrics, or a photo of the artist or the album cover. YouTube also has licenses from ASCAP, BMI and SESAC.

You can’t legally use someone else’s work without permission. It doesn’t matter if you are only sharing with three people or 3 million. What you need to do is just music for which the artists gave everyone permission to use it. One scheme for this is called Creative Commons: Creative Commons: Where can I find good CC-licensed music? But you can’t just use a Beyonce track and expect YouTube to ignore that. They have systems that check all uploads for copyright infringing music.

Short answer is you have to remove the copyrighted music from your videos and license some music that you can legally use. There is no getting around the copyright flag in YouTube when you use somebody else’s intellectual property in your project without permission. It doesn't matter if you upload just for a few people or even just for yourself. It still needs to be legal.

Armin answered the question accurately, although you’d probably be requesting permissions for “the world” , not just the small group. May not be worth your time; unfortunately, the whole music-rights thing is a bundle of 20th-century barbed wire. I got to see it up close a few years back and doubt it’ll get much better for at least a decade - if ever.

If it’s for your personal, charity purpose or academic purpose you may not be sued but if it’s for commercial purpose you can be sued. If you want to use the copy right music you must buy the same from the original artist/ producer by paying royalty or whatever you call.
